Hi,

ken wrote:

>Here is a well-recognized and interesting challenge:  Design a
>domain, maybe a robot domain like robot duel, where there is room
>for virtually *unlimited* ever-increasing complexity.  It turns out
>this is very hard to do, and most domains turn out to have a limit
>to how much intelligence can help after a certain point.  Such
>domains are called "open-ended," and designing them to be truly open-
>ended is perhaps as hard as AI itself.

         This is essentially the object of my Living@Home project.

         There's a web-page: http://livingathome.sourceforge.net/ but 
there's not a lot on it yet.  Actually that reminds me, I must kick the guy 
who's supposed to be revamping the web-pages...

         But basically the idea was:

- moderate complexity "physical" environment
- evolving body plan from a variety of pre-built components
- build the "brain" from:
1) low level evolving entities (such as NEAT-nets and/or GP-programs) -- 
call these "genes"
2) house the evolving entities in a "co-evolving support framework" (CSF) which
         2.1) specifies gene<->gene wiring
         2.2) specifies gene<->body wiring
         2.3) pattern matches gene's interests against sense input
         2.4) arbitrates conflicting gene output
         2.5) distributes resources (e.g. run time) between genes
         2.6) (maybe) handles "somantic learning" e.g. in crediting 
pleasure and pain to genes

It's a pretty complex area, and I'm only slowly coming up to speed on quite 
how hard it will be.  Obviously its important to try and draw up a series 
of staged prototypes so that we can move steadily towards the hard 
stuff.  But even that is complex :)

My current project is writting a "manifesto for evolving agents", which 
basically is about the gap between a "naked" evolving software technique 
(NEAT, GP, ...) and a whole evolving agent.

When it's done, I will invite comment, but it will be a while...

         Ian Badcoe
